# Chapter 4: Subpoena Infernum

The twelfth subpoena materialized at 11:47 PM, crackling into existence with the smell of burnt copper and old blood. Sarah caught it before it hit her desk, the parchment cold enough to burn her fingers. Like the eleven before it, this one bore seals she couldn't read and signatures that hurt to look at directly.

"Court of Eternal Contracts, Third District of Pandemonium," she read aloud, her voice hoarse from twelve hours of precedent research. The office around her looked like a law library had exploded—books scattered across every surface, some floating at eye level where she'd suspended them with basic levitation charms Diana had taught her. "They're claiming original jurisdiction over the Morrison verdict based on... seriously? A parking violation from 1987?"

Marcus looked up from his corner where he'd built a fort of casebooks, his eyes bloodshot but alert. "That's the thing about Hell's bureaucracy. They never delete anything. Every unpaid ticket, every jaywalking citation—it's all ammunition." He gestured at the growing pile of subpoenas. "Though twelve different courts claiming authority seems excessive, even for them."

"It's not excessive," Sarah said, spreading the documents across her desk like tarot cards. "It's vindictive. They want me to know they can reach me from any angle, through any jurisdiction." She touched each seal in turn, feeling the different textures of supernatural authority—some burned hot, others froze, one felt like drowning. "The Shadowlands District Court, the Tribunal of Broken Oaths, the Assembly of Unquiet Judgments... Christ, even the Small Claims Court of Lesser Demons filed one."

Her phone buzzed. Diana's text was brief: "Help coming. Clear the east wall."

Sarah barely had time to shove the floating books aside before three portals opened simultaneously against her office's eastern wall. The first shimmered with golden light that made her eyes water—through it stepped a man in priest's collar and an impeccable black suit. The second portal writhed with geometric patterns that seemed to fold in on themselves, admitting a woman in traditional Orthodox Jewish dress carrying a briefcase that hummed with barely contained energy. The third opened like a wound in reality, and through it came a tall man whose suit seemed woven from shadow itself, a prayer cap resting on his silver hair.

"Sarah Chen," the priest said, extending his hand. "Father Antonio Torretti, Vatican Office of Supernatural Jurisprudence. Diana said you needed expertise in multijurisdictional claiming conflicts."

"Rabbi Miriam Goldstein," the woman added, not offering to shake hands but nodding respectfully. "Jerusalem Council of Mystical Law. I've been fighting Pandemonium's overreach for thirty years."

The third figure bowed slightly. "Imam Rashid Al-Azhar, Cairo Institute of Juridical Theology. We came as soon as Diana explained your situation." His eyes, Sarah noticed, were completely black—not corrupted, but as if they reflected a night sky from another world entirely.

"I don't understand," Sarah said, looking between them. "Diana said most Advocates were too afraid of Magisterium retaliation to help."

"Most are," Father Antonio said, pulling an ancient leather tome from thin air. "But we three have something the others don't—diplomatic immunity from religious courts that predate the Magisterium by millennia. They can threaten us, but they can't touch us without starting a war they're not prepared to fight."

Rabbi Goldstein was already examining the subpoenas, her lips moving in what might have been Hebrew or something older. "Sloppy work. They're so eager to punish you, they didn't check their precedents properly. Look—" She pointed to specific seals on three different documents. "These courts claim authority through the Infernal Codex of 1666, but this one cites the Revision of 1823, and this references the Amsterdam Addendum that was never properly ratified."

"They contradict each other," Sarah breathed, understanding dawning.

"More than that," Imam Al-Azhar said, his voice carrying the weight of desert winds. "They create what we call a juridical paradox. If you respond to all of them simultaneously—"

"—they'll have to establish proper jurisdiction first," Sarah finished. "The binding curse can't execute if the authority behind it is in question."

Father Antonio opened his tome, and Sarah gasped. The pages weren't paper but something that might have been light given form. Text scrolled across them in languages that predated human speech. "There's more. Sacred contracts have primacy over infernal ones—it's written into the fundamental laws that govern all supernatural litigation. The divine preceded the damned, and even Hell's lawyers can't argue their way around that."

"But I'd need to invoke them properly," Sarah said, her mind racing. "And I'd need to know which sacred precedents apply to which infernal claim."

"Which is why we're here." Rabbi Goldstein set her briefcase on Sarah's desk and opened it. Inside, arranged like surgical instruments, were quills that seemed to contain starlight, ink that moved like living mercury, and seals older than civilization. "We have fifteen minutes to prepare a mass-filing ritual. Father Antonio will handle the Latin responses, I'll take the Aramaic and Hebrew portions, and Imam Al-Azhar will provide the Arabic components. You'll need to tie them all together with English common law structure."

They worked with the focused intensity of emergency room surgeons. Sarah's fingers flew across her keyboard, drafting responses that referenced both mundane and mystical precedents. Father Antonio chanted in Latin that made the air shimmer, while Rabbi Goldstein drew symbols in the air that hung like golden wire. Imam Al-Azhar spoke verses that seemed to make reality more solid, more real, as if reinforcing the foundations of the world itself.

At 11:58, Sarah stood in the center of a ritual circle drawn from three traditions—salt blessed by a priest, silver dust consecrated by a rabbi, and geometric patterns of sacred mathematics traced by an imam. The twelve subpoenas floated around her, each one pulling in a different direction, trying to tear her apart between jurisdictions.

"Remember," Father Antonio said, "you're not fighting the summons. You're asking them to fight each other."

Sarah took a breath that tasted of frankincense and possibilities. She began to speak, her voice carrying the weight of three thousand years of legal tradition: "I, Sarah Chen, recognized Advocate in the Court of Shadows, do hereby respond to all claimants simultaneously under the Doctrine of Contested Primacy, established in the Treaty of Solomon, ratified in the Concordat of Babylon, and recognized by all signatory powers of the Supernatural Legal Accords..."

The words poured out of her, each phrase precisely crafted to create maximum procedural conflict. The subpoenas began to vibrate, their competing authorities creating visible friction in the air. Sparks of gold, silver, and shadow collided as divine, mystical, and infernal law crashed against each other.

At exactly midnight, Sarah slammed her hand down on all twelve documents simultaneously—a physical impossibility made real through juridical sorcery. "I demand formal establishment of jurisdiction before any binding can take effect!"

The explosion was silent but profound. The subpoenas froze mid-air, their curses tangled in an endless loop of bureaucratic confusion. Each one insisted it had primacy, but none could prove it without acknowledging the others' claims. The binding that had been tightening around Sarah's throat dissolved into mist that smelled of frustrated paperwork.

"Brilliant," said a new voice from the doorway.

Everyone turned. A man stood there who hadn't been there a moment before—tall, distinguished, with silver hair and eyes the color of old parchment. He wore robes that might have been judicial or might have been shadows shaped like authority. When he smiled, Sarah noticed his teeth were too perfect, like a legal document with no loopholes.

"Judge Solomon Thorne," Father Antonio said carefully, and Sarah heard fear beneath his diplomatic tone. "We weren't expecting the Seventh Circuit Shadow Court to take interest."

"How could I not?" Thorne stepped into the office, and the floating subpoenas arranged themselves into a perfect circle, orbiting him like planets around a sun. "It's been years since someone created such an elegant juridical paradox. Ms. Chen, you have a gift."

"She has allies," Rabbi Goldstein said, stepping protectively closer to Sarah.

"Indeed. And powerful ones." Thorne's gaze swept over the three religious lawyers. "But allies can only teach so much. Ms. Chen needs a proper mentor, someone who understands both systems intimately." He focused on Sarah, and she felt the weight of centuries in his attention. "I'm prepared to offer you something your allies cannot—inside access to the Magisterium itself."

"In exchange for what?" Sarah asked, though she suspected she knew.

"Compliance with certain protocols. Nothing that would compromise your ethics—merely an acknowledgment that the system exists for a reason, and that working within it is more effective than fighting against it." Thorne raised his hand, and a pen materialized from shadow. With a gesture, he made it float and begin writing in the air, leaving trails of silver text. "This is juridical sorcery at its true level, Ms. Chen. The ability to rewrite reality through proper procedure."

The pen finished writing and the text solidified into a simple contract that hung in the air like a promise. Sarah read it—a mentorship agreement, seemingly straightforward, with terms that appeared surprisingly fair.

"Don't," Marcus whispered behind her.

But Sarah was already thinking three moves ahead. To fight the Magisterium, she needed to understand it from within. "I accept," she said, and took the floating pen.

The moment she signed, Thorne smiled—not unkindly, but with the satisfaction of a chess master who'd just gained a positional advantage. "Excellent. Your first lesson begins now." He waved his hand, and the contract she'd just signed began to shimmer. New text appeared between the lines—not hidden before, but literally written into existence after the fact. "This is the third text, Ms. Chen. The deepest level of magical meaning. Most lawyers see only the surface. Some, like your friends here, can perceive the second layer. But the third text... that's where true power resides."

Sarah stared at the contract, seeing meanings she hadn't imagined possible. Every word existed in three dimensions—its literal meaning, its legal implication, and its metaphysical weight. "This is what Michael discovered, isn't it?"

"Your husband was brilliant," Thorne said, and there was something in his tone that might have been genuine regret. "But brilliance without guidance leads to tragedy. I won't let that happen to you."

After the others left—Father Antonio through his golden portal, Rabbi Goldstein via geometric impossibility, Imam Al-Azhar dissolving into shadow—Marcus cornered Sarah by the coffee machine.

"You have no idea what you've just done," he said. "Solomon Thorne has mentored twelve lawyers in the last century. Want to know where they are now?"

"Tell me."

"Three run soul-trading firms in Manhattan. Two prosecute for the Infernal Revenue Service. Four serve as judges in various shadow courts, and they're the harsh ones—the ones who always rule against humanity. The other three?" Marcus paused. "No one knows. They just disappeared one day. Poof. Even their names were erased from the records."

"Maybe they found a way out," Sarah suggested.

"Or maybe they found out something they shouldn't have." Marcus pulled out his phone, showing her a database Diana had given him access to. "I've been researching while you were fighting subpoenas. Thorne has been the presiding judge on seventeen cases involving Michael's former clients. Every single one resulted in maximum supernatural sentences—soul fragmentations, eternal servitude, consciousness imprisonment. Either it's the world's biggest coincidence, or—"

"Or he was targeting Michael's work specifically." Sarah felt cold despite the office's warmth. "But why accept his mentorship if you knew this?"

"Because you're playing a longer game," Marcus said. It wasn't a question. "Just... be careful. Thorne's been doing this since before America was founded. He knows every trick you haven't even thought of yet."

The next morning came too quickly. Sarah arrived at the Shadow Courthouse to find Thorne waiting in a courtroom that existed in seven dimensions simultaneously. Her first assignment seemed simple enough: prosecute a ghost for trespassing.

"Standard procedure," Thorne explained, his voice echoing from angles that shouldn't exist. "The deceased, one Robert Henley, has been haunting 4421 North Ashland for six months. The current residents have filed a complaint. You'll argue for a standard banishment order."

The ghost materialized in the defendant's box—a middle-aged man in a bloodstained shirt, his form flickering between solid and translucent. He looked terrified.

Sarah approached the bench, feeling the weight of Thorne's expectation. But as she began her opening statement, Robert Henley spoke: "She killed me. The woman living in my house—she killed me and made it look like an accident. I'm not trespassing. I'm seeking justice."

The courtroom fell silent. Sarah felt Thorne watching her, testing her. The easy path was clear: ignore the ghost's claim, get the conviction, prove she could work within the system. But...

"Your Honor," Sarah said, turning to face Thorne, "I move to convert this trespassing charge into a murder investigation. Under Spectral Rights Code 7.3.2, a ghost maintaining presence at the site of their death has standing to file charges against their killer."

"That's an obscure precedent," Thorne noted, his expression unreadable.

"But a valid one. Mr. Henley isn't trespassing—he's a victim exercising his posthumous legal rights. I can prosecute him for trespassing, or I can help him file proper charges against his murderer. The law allows for both, but justice demands the latter."

The ghost's form solidified with hope. Thorne leaned back in his chair, which existed in too many dimensions to properly perceive. "And if I order you to proceed with the trespassing charge?"

"Then I'll proceed," Sarah said. "But I'll also file a concurrent brief on Mr. Henley's behalf, creating a procedural conflict that will tie this case up in bureaucratic loops for decades. The residents won't get their banishment order, Mr. Henley won't get justice, and the court's time will be wasted on what could be resolved today."

Thorne laughed—a sound like wind through empty halls. "You're using the system's own complexity against itself. How delightfully subversive." He stood, his robes flowing in directions that defied physics. "Motion granted. Mr. Henley, you have standing to file charges. Ms. Chen will assist you in preparing the proper documentation."

As the ghost tearfully thanked her, Thorne approached. "That was a test," he said quietly. "I wanted to see if you could balance justice with procedure, ethics with efficiency. You passed."

"By defying you?"

"By finding a third option. The best lawyers don't choose between bad alternatives—they create new possibilities within existing frameworks." He handed her a card that felt like frozen mercury. "Your next lesson is tomorrow. We'll be reviewing some of my past cases. I think you'll find them... instructive."

That evening, Diana was waiting in Sarah's office with a box of files that smelled like dust and dread. "I pulled Thorne's case history. Look at this pattern." She spread documents across the desk, each one marked with Michael's handwriting in the margins. "Seventeen cases, all involving Michael's clients, all resulting in maximum sentences. But look at the dates."

Sarah studied them, and her blood chilled. "They're all from the last fifteen years. But Thorne's been a judge for over two centuries."

"Exactly. So I went deeper." Diana pulled out older files, their pages yellowed with age. "His early cases show a completely different pattern. Lenient sentences, creative solutions that favored human defendants, even some acquittals that pissed off the Infernal prosecutors. Something changed fifteen years ago."

"What happened fifteen years ago?"

"That's what I'm trying to figure out. But Sarah..." Diana pointed to one specific case file. "This was his last lenient ruling. The defendant was a lawyer who'd discovered something called Project Convergence. Three days after Thorne ruled in his favor, the lawyer disappeared. A week later, Thorne started issuing harsh sentences. It's like he became a different person overnight."

Sarah picked up the file, feeling the weight of old secrets in its pages. As she did, something fell out—a sealed envelope with her name on it in Michael's handwriting. Her hands shook as she opened it.

"Sarah," Michael's letter began, "if you're reading this, it means you've started down the same path I did. By now you've probably met Solomon Thorne. He'll seem like an ally, maybe even a friend. But there's something you need to know. Fifteen years ago, Thorne tried to stop Project Convergence. He failed. What came back wearing his face isn't entirely him anymore. The judge who wears Solomon's wisdom like a mask is both victim and villain. Be careful. The greatest trap isn't the one that looks like a trap—it's the one that looks like salvation."

Sarah looked up from the letter to find Diana watching her with concern. "He knew," Sarah said. "Michael knew about Thorne, about all of this."

"And it got him killed," Diana said gently. "The question is: what are you going to do with that knowledge?"

Sarah stood at her window, watching the city lights below—each one representing thousands of people who had no idea they were one contract away from supernatural servitude. The subpoenas still hung frozen in her office, a testament to her growing power. Thorne's card sat on her desk, promising knowledge and corruption in equal measure. Michael's warning burned in her pocket.

She had a choice to make: abandon Thorne's mentorship and lose inside access to the Magisterium, or continue learning from him while knowing he might be the very thing she was fighting against. Either path could lead to Michael's fate.

But maybe, like with the ghost's case, there was a third option.

Sarah picked up her phone and sent a text to Marcus: "Research everything about what happened fifteen years ago. Focus on Project Convergence and any lawyers who disappeared around that time."

Then she sent another to Diana: "Keep monitoring Thorne's current cases. Look for patterns, especially anything involving consent or jurisdiction."

Finally, she texted the number Father Antonio had given her: "Need to know about exorcism law. Specifically, partial possession and judicial authority."

If Solomon Thorne was both victim and villain, as Michael suggested, then perhaps the real challenge wasn't defeating him or learning from him. Perhaps it was finding a way to save him while using his knowledge against the very system that had corrupted him.

Sarah smiled grimly. It would be like performing legal surgery with the patient awake and armed. But then again, she'd just turned twelve demonic subpoenas against each other through sheer procedural creativity.

Impossible was becoming her specialty.

The moon hung over Chicago like a judge's eye, watching as Sarah began to plan her most dangerous case yet: defending Solomon Thorne against whatever had claimed him fifteen years ago, while pretending to be his obedient student.

Tomorrow's lesson would be instructive indeed—just not in the way Thorne expected.

# Chapter 5: The Tenant's Lament

The eviction notice trembled in Rosa Martinez's weathered hands, the paper crackling like autumn leaves. Sarah watched the woman's fingers—gnarled as winter branches, spotted with age—trace the legal text that would cast her into the street. Those hands belonged to someone who should be shopping for her daughter's wedding dress, not fighting to keep a roof over her head. According to the birth certificate Marcus had pulled, Rosa Martinez was forty years old.

"Three years," Rosa whispered, her voice carrying the rasp of decades. "Three years in this place, and look at me." She raised her face to the fluorescent lights of Sarah's cramped conference room, revealing deep grooves that mapped a geography of suffering. "My grandson, he meant well. Said the rent was so cheap, said it would help me save."

Sarah set down her coffee—it had gone cold anyway—and pulled the lease agreement across the scarred table. The standard English text looked mundane enough: two-bedroom unit, $400 monthly, utilities included. But when she shifted her perception, letting her eyes drift into that space Diana had taught her to see, the Sumerian cuneiform writhed beneath like parasites under skin.

"Mrs. Martinez, did your grandson read the entire lease?"

"He's a good boy. Works two jobs, no time for reading all that tiny print." Rosa's laugh held no humor. "Who reads every word anyway?"

Marcus leaned over Sarah's shoulder, his breath catching as he parsed the ancient text. "Jesus Christ. It's not rent they're collecting."

Sarah's finger traced the hidden clause, her legal training automatically translating the archaic terms into modern horror: *The Tenant agrees to render unto the Proprietor one-twelfth of their remaining mortal span per lunar cycle, such essence to be collected through proximity to the Foundation Stones, payment considered complete upon termination of corporeal existence or contractual period, whichever manifests first.*

"We need to see the building," Sarah said.

Rosa's face crumpled. "You believe me? The other lawyers, they said I was crazy. Said I needed a doctor, not an attorney."

"I believe you're forty years old, Mrs. Martinez. And I believe something in that building stole thirty years of your life."

* * *

The apartment complex squatted on Ashland Avenue like a cancer in brick and mortar. Sarah felt it before she saw it—a wrongness that made her teeth ache and her bones feel hollow. The November wind should have been cold, but the air around the building hung thick and still, pregnant with the smell of rust and rotting flowers.

Marcus stopped at the property line. "You feel that?"

Sarah nodded. The sensation was like standing at the edge of a cliff, that primitive brain-stem certainty that one more step meant death. But Rosa Martinez lived here. Had lived here for three years while the building fed on her like a tick grown fat with blood.

"The landlord's expecting us," Sarah said, forcing her feet forward.

Mr. Graves waited in the lobby, and Sarah understood immediately why his tenants aged so rapidly. The man—if man was even the right word—existed as an absence rather than a presence. Where he stood, the world seemed thinner, colors bleeding out like a photograph left in the sun. The plastic ficus by the mailboxes had turned brown and brittle in the time it took them to cross the lobby, its leaves crumbling to dust.

"Ms. Chen." His voice had the quality of settling foundations, of structures slowly failing. "I understand there's been some confusion about our rental agreements."

"My client claims she's lost thirty years of her life."

Graves smiled, an expression that never reached his eyes—black, flat things like holes punched through reality. "Tenants often complain. The economy, you understand. Everyone wants something for nothing."

"Show me the building."

"Of course."

They climbed stairs that groaned with more than age. Sarah counted the sounds: her heels clicking on worn linoleum, Marcus's nervous breathing, the whisper of Rosa's orthopedic shoes, and underneath it all, a rhythm like a massive heart beating somewhere deep in the building's bones. The walls themselves pulsed, so subtle she might have imagined it if she hadn't been looking for it.

Graves unlocked apartment 3B. "As you can see, we maintain our units to code."

The apartment was immaculate and empty, but Sarah's trained perception caught the truth underneath. The walls breathed. Actually breathed, expanding and contracting in slow tidal movements. In the corners where wall met ceiling, veins of something dark pulsed with stolen time. The air tasted of copper and regret.

"How many units?" Sarah asked.

"Forty-eight. All occupied."

Forty-eight tenants. If each lost ten years per year of residency, if the average stay was two years... Sarah's mind reeled at the mathematics of it. Nearly a thousand years of human life, processed and packaged and sold.

"The Foundation Stones," she said. "I want to see them."

Graves's expression never changed, but the temperature dropped ten degrees. Ice formed on the windows in fractal patterns. "That would be... inadvisable."

"My client has the right to understand what she's paying for."

"Your client signed a binding agreement."

"In Sumerian. Without translation. Without informed consent."

"Ignorance of the law—"

"Is no excuse. I know." Sarah pulled out her phone, pretending to check messages while actually recording. "But fraud vitiates all contracts. Show me the Foundation Stones, Mr. Graves, or I'll file for immediate injunctive relief."

The thing wearing Graves's face considered this. "Very well."

* * *

The basement door required three keys and what looked like a blood sample. Graves pressed his thumb to a reader that glowed sickly green, and Sarah heard locks disengaging deep in the earth. The stairs descended far longer than any basement had a right to, the walls transitioning from drywall to brick to carved stone that predated Chicago by centuries.

The smell hit first—sweet rot and burning metal, the scent of time itself decomposing. Then came the sound: a mechanical thrumming like industrial equipment, punctuated by something that might have been screaming if screams could fossilize.

The Foundation Stones filled a cavern that shouldn't have existed beneath a three-story apartment building. Seven obsidian pillars, each twenty feet tall, their surfaces carved with Sumerian that hurt to read. Between them, suspended in crackling nets of energy, hung years. Actual years, pulled from human lives and condensed into something visible—golden threads that writhed like living things, desperate to return to their owners.

"A life mill," Marcus breathed. "I thought they were urban legends."

"Everything's real somewhere," Graves said. "This is a perfectly legal operation. The Magisterium approved the permits in 1953."

Sarah watched a new thread materialize, pulled from somewhere above—from one of the forty-eight apartments where someone was aging one more day, one more hour, one more irreplaceable moment. The thread joined the others, wound into skeins that pulsed with stolen potential.

"What do you do with them?" she asked.

"I'm a wholesaler, Ms. Chen. My clients value quality product. Human years, ethically sourced through legal contracts, command premium prices in certain markets."

"Ethically sourced."

"Every tenant signed."

"In a language they couldn't read."

"As I said—ignorance of the law."

Sarah took photos with her phone, knowing the images would be blurred, knowing the court might not admit them, knowing she was gathering evidence for a case she couldn't win. Not in any court that mattered. Not yet.

"I've seen enough."

* * *

Back in her office, Sarah spread the documents across her desk like tarot cards revealing a terrible future. The lease agreement. The eviction notice. Rosa Martinez's medical records showing cellular aging consistent with someone in their seventies. The building permits, filed in 1953, that somehow predated the building itself by twenty years.

Her phone buzzed. Thorne.

"I understand you visited the Ashland Avenue property today."

"News travels fast."

"Mr. Graves has retained our firm. He wants you specifically."

Sarah's coffee mug stopped halfway to her lips. "He wants me to represent him?"

"Against your Mrs. Martinez, yes. Consider it a test of your professional objectivity."

"I can't—"

"You can and you will. Unless you'd prefer to explain to the Magisterium why you're refusing a client based on personal bias? They take such things seriously."

The line went dead. Sarah stared at the phone, then at Rosa Martinez's intake form, then at the hidden text writhing beneath the surface of every document. Thorne was testing her. Or trapping her. Maybe both.

Diana materialized in the chair across from her desk—not literally, though Sarah was learning never to rule anything out. The other lawyer had a talent for appearing when needed least and wanted most.

"You're going to take the case," Diana said. It wasn't a question.

"I don't have a choice."

"There's always a choice. It's just that some choices end with you dissolved into your component atoms and scattered across seventeen dimensions."

"Comforting."

Diana picked up the lease agreement, her fingers tracing the Sumerian. "Life mills are the backbone of the supernatural economy. Demons need human years like humans need oil. Challenge one, you challenge them all."

"Good."

"No, not good. Catastrophic. Do you know what a precedent cascade is?"

Sarah shook her head.

"Legal precedent shapes reality in Magisterium courts. Literally. Win a case that says life mills require explicit, knowing consent for each year taken, and suddenly every life mill in existence is in violation. The entire supernatural economy collapses overnight. The Magisterium will not allow that."

"So I'm supposed to defend him? Help him evict a woman he's killing?"

"I'm saying be clever. Be subtle. Be very, very careful."

Diana vanished, leaving only the scent of sulfur and expensive perfume.

* * *

Sarah spent the night in the law library's restricted section, the one that required blood verification to enter. The Codex Infernum sat chained to its podium, its pages made from something that wasn't quite leather and wasn't quite human skin but existed uncomfortably between the two. Every precedent she found supported Graves. Centuries of case law establishing that consent, once given, covered all consequences whether understood or not.

But then, in a footnote to a footnote in a case from 1823, she found it: *Temporis Vitae v. The People of Orleans Parish*. A life mill shut down not for the theft itself, but for imprecise language. The court had ruled that each year taken required its own consent, clearly stated, in a language the signer comprehended.

It was tissue-thin. It would never hold. Unless...

Sarah pulled out her phone and called Rosa Martinez's grandson.

"Miguel? It's Sarah Chen. I need you to do something for me. I need you to file a complaint. Not for your grandmother—for yourself. As the person who actually signed the lease."

* * *

The courtroom existed in both realms simultaneously, a disorienting overlay of wood paneling and shadow, fluorescent lights and flames that burned without heat. Judge Maureen Blackstone presided, her robes shifting between black polyester and something that absorbed light like a hole in the world.

Sarah sat at the defendant's table, Mr. Graves beside her radiating cold that made her fingers numb. Across the aisle, Father Antonio Vega arranged his papers with practiced precision. She'd expected some junior prosecutor. Instead, the Vatican had sent one of their best.

"Your Honor," Sarah began, standing on legs that felt disconnected from her body. "The defendant moves for summary judgment. The lease agreement is clear, consent was given, and my client has every right to enforce the terms."

She made the argument perfectly. Every citation correct, every precedent supporting Graves's position. She also made sure to enter every single violation into the record. The Sumerian text. The lack of translation. The forty-eight units. The thousand stolen years.

Father Antonio rose. "Your Honor, the sanctity of human life supersedes any commercial agreement. The Vatican cites the Concordat of Solomon, which clearly states—"

"The Concordat has no standing in property disputes," Sarah interrupted, hating herself. "If opposing counsel wishes to make a religious argument—"

Graves stood suddenly, his human mask slipping. The temperature plummeted. Ice spread across the windows in patterns that hurt to follow. His true form bled through—something ancient and hungry, all angles and appetite.

"ENOUGH!" His voice shattered the water glasses on both tables. "These insects dare challenge my rightful harvest? I have fed on their years since before their miserable city existed! I will drain them all, every last—"

"Mr. Graves." Sarah's voice cut through his rage. "You're in contempt of court."

The demon turned to her, and for a moment she saw her death in seventeen different ways. Then recognition flickered in those inhuman eyes. The trap she'd laid. The words he'd spoken. In open court. On the record.

Judge Blackstone's gavel came down like thunder. "Mr. Graves, you will maintain proper form in my courtroom."

But it was too late. The outburst had violated attorney-client privilege. Sarah could withdraw. More importantly, she could act.

"Your Honor, I move to withdraw as counsel due to my client's breach of professional conduct."

"Granted."

Sarah gathered her papers, then paused. "Your Honor, I also wish to file a cross-complaint on behalf of all affected tenants, based on evidence discovered during my representation."

"You can't—" Graves started.

"I can. Attorney-client privilege was voided by your outburst. Everything I learned while representing you is now admissible."

She handed the clerk a document she'd prepared the night before, every word chosen with surgical precision. Father Antonio's eyes widened as he read over her shoulder. He understood what she'd done.

Judge Blackstone reviewed the filing, her expression unreadable. "This is highly irregular."

"But legal."

"Yes." The word seemed pulled from the judge against her will. "The court will consider your cross-complaint."

* * *

The ruling came down three hours later. Sarah stood between Rosa Martinez and Miguel as Judge Blackstone read from a document that rewrote reality with every word.

"The court finds that the lease agreements, while technically valid, failed to secure informed consent for each specific year of life taken. Per *Temporis Vitae v. The People of Orleans Parish*, such extraction requires explicit agreement for each unit of time harvested."

Graves made a sound like tearing metal.

"Furthermore, this court orders the immediate return of all stolen years to their rightful owners. All similar leases within this jurisdiction are hereby void."

The building on Ashland Avenue screamed.

Sarah felt it through the soles of her feet, through the fillings in her teeth—the death cry of a life mill as it regurgitated decades of stolen time. Somewhere, Rosa Martinez would wake up tomorrow looking fifty instead of seventy. Somewhere, forty-seven other tenants would reclaim years they'd thought lost forever.

And somewhere, dozens of other life mills suddenly faced the same fate.

* * *

"You clever, clever girl." Thorne's voice held equal parts admiration and threat. They stood in the parking garage beneath the courthouse, shadows moving in ways shadows shouldn't. "Do you have any idea what you've done?"

"My job."

"You've disrupted an economy that's existed for millennia."

"I've enforced the law. Your law. Using your precedents."

He stepped closer, and Sarah felt the weight of his true nature pressing against her mind. "The Magisterium will not forget this."

"Good. Maybe they'll think twice before asking me to defend another demon."

Thorne laughed, a sound like breaking glass. "Oh, Sarah. You still don't understand. This was never about defending Graves. This was about seeing what you would do when forced to choose between justice and survival."

"I chose justice."

"You chose war."

He vanished, leaving Sarah alone in the fluorescent hum of the parking garage. She walked to her car on unsteady legs, her keys jangling in trembling fingers. The victory felt hollow, temporary. She'd won a battle but declared herself an enemy in a war she barely understood.

Her office door stood open when she returned, though she'd locked it. Papers scattered across the floor like dead birds. Every file cabinet emptied, their contents shredded with inhuman precision. And on her desk, where Michael's photo had sat for two years, only empty space and a note written in Sumerian.

Marcus translated it, his face going pale: "You'll join him soon."

Sarah picked up the empty picture frame, running her fingers along its edges. Michael had fought this fight. Had died for it. Or been killed for it. The distinction mattered less than the result—he was gone, and she was here, and the work continued.

"They're trying to scare me," she said.

"Is it working?"

Sarah thought about Rosa Martinez's tears when the years returned, flooding back into her body like water into drought-cracked earth. She thought about forty-seven other tenants waking up to reclaimed decades. She thought about Michael, who'd known the cost and paid it anyway.

"No," she said, and meant it. "It's not working at all."

Outside, Chicago churned on, oblivious to the supernatural economy hemorrhaging in its shadows. But in law offices and courtrooms, in the spaces between what was legal and what was right, the word was spreading: someone had killed a life mill. Someone had challenged the system and won.

Sarah Chen had painted a target on her back visible in seventeen dimensions.

She was ready for whatever came next.
